quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: M&A is always about creating plan Bs.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Frames M&A as a strategic optionality tool rather than an endgame, guiding how founders should think about it early.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And the way I would think about it is for any one company, there's only ever two to three buyers that find what you're building to be extremely strategic.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A concrete mental model for narrowing your M&A target set and focusing relationship-building and positioning efforts.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And I would inflict pain on that potential buyer. Make it impossible for them to not notice you because that's when they're going to have their ears perk up and say, "Well, what's going on with this company?"
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice: create competitive pressure to get on an incumbent’s radar and trigger strategic interest.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The really important piece here is you want to do that in a way that's still friendly and open.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Adds a practical constraint to the “inflict pain” strategy—compete hard while keeping channels open for partnership or acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: But that's a mistake because M&A is all about creating plan Bs and you don't want to shut that door down prematurely because you don't know if you can really go the distance and be an independent company. So you want to have optionality.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Warns founders against cutting off incumbents too early, emphasizing optionality when independence is uncertain.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta to help build scale, manage, and demonstrate their security and compliance programs and get ready for audits in weeks, not months.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta read)
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete operational outcome—compressing audit readiness timelines—which is a practical lever for scaling teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 best scoring companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta read)
quotes.context: Provides a specific adoption and automation claim that can inform build-vs-buy decisions for compliance workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Teams who use Superhuman spend half the time in their inboxes respond to twice the number of emails and save over four hours a week.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Superhuman read)
quotes.context: Quantifies productivity impact, offering a benchmark for evaluating email/process tooling ROI.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Superhuman, you can split your inbox into streams for VIPs, team members and emails from your favorite products to reduce context switching.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Superhuman read)
quotes.context: A simple workflow pattern (inbox segmentation) that practitioners can apply to reduce context switching and improve responsiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can start reminders if you don't hear back so that you can follow up and never drop the ball on an email thread.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Superhuman read)
quotes.context: Actionable tactic for building reliable follow-up systems and preventing dropped commitments in async communication.

quotes.topic_title: From VC to product at dbt
quotes.text: For me, I've always had three interests broadly and that's an interest in business, an interest in technology and an interest in markets. And I get to express those interests both in investing and in product, but just with different weights.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A simple framework for mapping career moves by identifying core interests and how different roles weight them.

quotes.topic_title: From VC to product at dbt
quotes.text: And I got really very, very excited about dbt because when I talked to people that were using it, the way that they described their experience on dbt was like unlike anything I had heard before. It was much more of an identity for them than just a tool that they were using to get their job done.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A practical signal for spotting breakout products early: users describe it as part of their identity, not just utility.

quotes.topic_title: From VC to product at dbt
quotes.text: Cloud data warehouses were starting to explode. This was the year where Snowflake went from a 4 billion company to a 12 billion company.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A concrete market-timing data point she used to justify why dbt could scale unusually fast.

quotes.topic_title: From VC to product at dbt
quotes.text: I was just so convicted that if was going to be a special company that I asked to even put my personal money in and I asked to put a very irresponsible, irrational amount, nearly like 20% of my liquid net worth into dbt because I was so convinced that this was special.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: An extreme example of conviction as a decision-making heuristic when you believe you’ve found an outlier.

quotes.topic_title: From VC to product at dbt
quotes.text: And sometimes when deals don't work out as an investor, you can create this narrative in your head like, "Good, I dodged a bullet or better off without them or screw them." But for me that was quite the opposite with dbt. I really felt like dbt was this runaway train and it was special and I wanted to jump on board.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A counterintuitive mindset: treat losing a deal as a prompt to reassess conviction rather than rationalize it away.

quotes.topic_title: How to evaluate early-stage companies
quotes.text: So there are four things that I care about when I'm looking at really early stage companies and it's people, market, product and distribution.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A simple, reusable four-part framework for evaluating early-stage companies (whether joining or investing).

quotes.topic_title: How to evaluate early-stage companies
quotes.text: And then the last, I think this is more important arguably than if they have a good product but is distribution, do they have an advantage on how are they going to get to market because that's really, really hard?
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A contrarian prioritization: distribution advantage can matter more than product quality in early-stage success.

quotes.topic_title: How to evaluate early-stage companies
quotes.text: You're not going to get a 10 out of 10 on all four dimensions. So when you're joining a company, you also have the benefit of dedicating your time. So try to think if they're weaker on one dimension, what is it that you bring to the table or what are you special at that could potentially de-risk the success of the company
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Practical advice for candidates: evaluate gaps across the four dimensions and join where your strengths reduce risk.

quotes.topic_title: How to evaluate early-stage companies
quotes.text: Yeah. It's can they not stop talking about it and that's the chatter about a product, they want to share it with their teammates or to other people at different companies.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A concrete heuristic for product “spark”: users’ compulsive sharing and word-of-mouth behavior.

quotes.topic_title: How to evaluate early-stage companies
quotes.text: So dbt had an ecosystem advantage and they were open source and this helped really dramatically for lots of people to have low barrier friction to just try it out and spread organically.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A specific example of distribution advantage: open source lowers adoption friction and enables organic spread.

quotes.topic_title: M&A strategy: create optionality and leverage
quotes.text: When it comes to acquisitions, the time to start thinking about an M&A strategy is hopefully when you don't need one.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A counterintuitive timing principle: plan M&A early to maximize leverage and options before you’re forced into it.

quotes.topic_title: M&A strategy: create optionality and leverage
quotes.text: And if you have that path, then you'll have the upper hand in absolutely every single M&A conversation because you have a viable alternative, which is do nothing, stay the course, you don't have to sell.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A negotiation framework: the strongest M&A leverage comes from a credible standalone plan (a real BATNA).

quotes.topic_title: M&A strategy: create optionality and leverage
quotes.text: So M&A is always about creating plan Bs.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A simple mental model for founders: treat M&A as optionality-building rather than a last-resort exit.

quotes.topic_title: M&A strategy: create optionality and leverage
quotes.text: And the way I would think about it is for any one company, there's only ever two to three buyers that find what you're building to be extremely strategic.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A practical targeting heuristic: focus M&A efforts on the tiny set of truly strategic acquirers instead of “the market.”

quotes.topic_title: M&A strategy: create optionality and leverage
quotes.text: I would figure out the area that you bring a competitive advantage and I would inflict pain on that potential buyer. Make it impossible for them to not notice you because that's when they're going to have their ears perk up and say, "Well, what's going on with this company?"
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: An actionable go-to-market tactic for getting on acquirers’ radar: compete in a way that forces attention without burning bridges.

quotes.topic_title: Transform acquisition: pain, partnership, and fit
quotes.text: What we had at dbt Labs is really good distribution and ecosystem, but we were a little behind in bringing a product to market and we felt that pressure from Transform because they were doing such a great job at being vocal and loud about how their semantic layer solves these really hard technical problems.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Highlights a practical competitive dynamic: strong distribution can be offset by a competitor’s speed and narrative clarity around hard technical wins.

quotes.topic_title: Transform acquisition: pain, partnership, and fit
quotes.text: But they didn't have any distribution.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A crisp reminder that product strength alone can stall without a go-to-market channel, shaping partnership or acquisition outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Transform acquisition: pain, partnership, and fit
quotes.text: So because they had positioned themselves as a friendly partner when really we were trying to compete for this similar use case, when it came time to do an acquisition, we were really excited because we knew their product was good and they had already done a lot of the work to make integrating with dbt possible and that helps us post acquisition do the integration much more easily.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Shows an actionable M&A playbook: compete while partnering, and pre-build integration paths to make acquisition (and post-merger integration) easier.

quotes.topic_title: dbt’s competition philosophy and platform strategy
quotes.text: But we really have three pillars when it comes to competition. So the first is hold true to our vision.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Introduces a simple, repeatable framework teams can use to guide competitive strategy decisions.

quotes.topic_title: dbt’s competition philosophy and platform strategy
quotes.text: If you have a lot of conviction that you're going in the right journey, you want to just keep your eyes straight ahead and run your best race and not be too distracted by what maybe some critics are saying.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Actionable advice on reducing competitor-driven distraction and focusing execution on a clear strategy.

quotes.topic_title: dbt’s competition philosophy and platform strategy
quotes.text: The second philosophy we have is really a grow the pie philosophy.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A partner-first mental model that reframes competition as expanding the market rather than fighting over share.

quotes.topic_title: dbt’s competition philosophy and platform strategy
quotes.text: Now with this big wave of ML, clean Transform data assets are being used to train machine learning models so that the pie continues to grow.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Concrete example of how adjacent technology waves (ML) expand the addressable market for core data capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: dbt’s competition philosophy and platform strategy
quotes.text: And generally speaking, when it comes to competition, we take a really long-term view and there are a few areas that we do want to hold our ground and that's in our transformation standard as well as our semantic standard because we believe those two are better served together for the user's sake.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A nuanced platform strategy: partner broadly, but defend a small set of key standards that compound user value.

quotes.topic_title: Why dbt won: simplicity, openness, and timing
quotes.text: it's true like dbt is really simple, but that is the power of it.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product lesson: simplicity can be the differentiator even when the underlying idea seems “straightforward.”

quotes.topic_title: Why dbt won: simplicity, openness, and timing
quotes.text: So dbt was really this belief that if you know SQL, we want to invite you to do these workflows that were traditionally held by data engineers but you had to earn that.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A clear adoption framework: expand the builder base by moving “production” workflows to adjacent roles, but with guardrails.

quotes.topic_title: Why dbt won: simplicity, openness, and timing
quotes.text: So dbt is really easy to get started with at your company with reduced friction.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Actionable go-to-market insight: reduce initial friction to accelerate internal and cross-company sharing and adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Why dbt won: simplicity, openness, and timing
quotes.text: So we have 20,000 companies using dbt every single week and that attracts partners to want to build for dbt and so they share best practices, build workflows, and now if you're a company and you've standardized on dbt, you've really unlocked an integrated modern data ecosystem that wasn't available for you before.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A concrete data point plus ecosystem flywheel: scale attracts partners, which increases value for standardizing customers.

quotes.topic_title: Why dbt won: simplicity, openness, and timing
quotes.text: I think timing was really important with the success of dbt. That they were there when the cloud data warehouses were really exploding and growing in an enormous way.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A reminder that product success often depends on aligning with a platform shift (here, cloud warehouse adoption).

quotes.topic_title: Consulting roots and customer-driven product building
quotes.text: Okay. So they basically spent two years solving this problem basically manually for people, and that's such a great way to understand real pain and figure out how to solve it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical methodology: do the work manually first to deeply understand customer pain before productizing.

quotes.topic_title: Consulting roots and customer-driven product building
quotes.text: Well, they were building dbt and using dbt to help them do their jobs better and supporting their clients.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Shows a tight feedback loop where the team uses the product in real client work to accelerate learning and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Consulting roots and customer-driven product building
quotes.text: And whenever they encountered paper cuts or friction or the workflow was taking longer than they expected, they would build that into dbt.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Provides an actionable product-building heuristic: systematically convert recurring workflow friction into product improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Consulting roots and customer-driven product building
quotes.text: And that really matured the experience of the product because the people who were building it, the founders were also day-to-day working with these customers or clients that had pain points.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Explains why consulting roots can be a product advantage: builders stay close to real users and their pain daily.

quotes.topic_title: Hands-on team learning: rope-and-graph algorithm exercise
quotes.text: And I needed a way for the team to really internalize all of the changes that we were going to be making and I needed them to own it because otherwise they wouldn't be able to anticipate all of the edge cases and it wouldn't be quite as durable. You couldn't copy paste the algorithm.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A practical rationale for designing learning so the whole team can anticipate edge cases rather than relying on a few experts or documentation.

quotes.topic_title: Hands-on team learning: rope-and-graph algorithm exercise
quotes.text: So I showed up to a team offsite with a spool of rope and sticky notes and I think my team looked at me crazy, went with two heads when I started to tie people up to create a graph. So each note of the graph was an engineer and the rope was the edges of the graph to connect them. And then we worked through the new algorithm extremely slowly, step by step.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A memorable, replicable methodology: physically modeling a system (DAG) to force shared understanding through embodied participation.

quotes.topic_title: Hands-on team learning: rope-and-graph algorithm exercise
quotes.text: And it was a way that you couldn't leave that exercise without knowing exactly what was going on because everyone had a role to play.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Highlights a team-learning design principle: assign every person an active role to ensure comprehension and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Hands-on team learning: rope-and-graph algorithm exercise
quotes.text: So I think a lot of times when you're starting something new, you get into a situation where a few people really understand it and they're running way ahead of the rest of the pack. But I needed a way for the whole team to go along for the journey.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Calls out a common failure mode in new projects and frames a countermeasure: engineer the learning curve so the team progresses together.

quotes.topic_title: Hands-on team learning: rope-and-graph algorithm exercise
quotes.text: We were trying to figure out how to make flipping the way that we run people's dags from an imperative way to a declarative way. So instead of running things left to when data arrived in your warehouse. You think about it as reverse, like what would need to happen to make your data SLAs be materialized in time.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A concrete example of a mental model shift (imperative → declarative) that practitioners can apply when redesigning orchestration around outcomes/SLAs.

quotes.topic_title: Open source vs proprietary: what dbt charges for
quotes.text: We think about dbt open source. It's really the guts of the data transformation. It's where you describe your business logic.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Defines a clear boundary for what belongs in open source: the core transformation logic and business rules.

quotes.topic_title: Open source vs proprietary: what dbt charges for
quotes.text: And then on the cloud side we build proprietary software that supercharges the development life cycle and the productionization of dbt at scale.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Actionable open-core monetization model: charge for workflow acceleration and scaling/production features rather than the core engine.

quotes.topic_title: Open source vs proprietary: what dbt charges for
quotes.text: So what we think about as leaving for our cloud offering is we deal with state, so stateful interactions and also any cross team or structural collaboration.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Practical rule-of-thumb for packaging: keep “state” and collaboration as paid features while leaving core logic open.

quotes.topic_title: Open source vs proprietary: what dbt charges for
quotes.text: And I think it's really important to have that distinction of what do you believe should be open source or what is the open standard that really matters?
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A decision framework for open source strategy: identify the “open standard” that must remain open to drive adoption and trust.

quotes.topic_title: Open source vs proprietary: what dbt charges for
quotes.text: So it's important that that remains open source, but then we want to supercharge that experience with an open core model and build proprietary software that makes people much more successful at using dbt.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Captures the open-core philosophy: keep the ecosystem open while monetizing software that increases user success in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're looking to build AI powered features in your audio and video products, then you need to know about AssemblyAI, which makes it easy to transcribe and understand speech at scale.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical use case and value proposition for teams building AI features on audio/video: transcription and speech understanding at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What I love about AssemblyAI is you can use their simple API to access the latest AI breakthroughs from top tier research labs.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable product-building approach: leverage an API abstraction to ship cutting-edge AI without doing the research yourself.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Product team that startups and enterprises are using AssemblyAI to automatically transcribe and summarize phone calls and virtual meetings, detect topics in podcasts, pinpoint when sensitive content spoken and lots more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides concrete examples of high-value workflows (summarization, topic detection, sensitive-content pinpointing) practitioners can apply immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So many PMs I know are considering or already building with AI and AssemblyAI is the fastest way to build with AI for audio use cases.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A speed-to-market heuristic for PMs: use specialized platforms to accelerate AI feature delivery in a specific domain (audio).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now's the time to check out AssemblyAI, which makes it easy to bring the highest accuracy transcription plus valuable insights to your customers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes a customer-value framing for AI features: pair accuracy with downstream insights, not just raw transcription.

quotes.topic_title: Pricing: willingness-to-pay, elasticity, and process
quotes.text: you don't get to decide if you're going to have a pricing or willingness to pay a conversation. You only get to decide what. So it's much better to have that conversation before you build the product than have it when your sales team's trying to sell something and people aren't excited about what you've built, aren't willing to pay for it.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes pricing as inevitable and argues for doing willingness-to-pay discovery before product build.

quotes.topic_title: Pricing: willingness-to-pay, elasticity, and process
quotes.text: When we talk about what is the value of dbt Labs to our customers, they often talk about how it's either 20 to 35% as valuable as what they spend on their cloud data warehouse. But what we charge our customers is a very small fraction of that 20 to 35% and that's by design.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A concrete benchmarking approach (relative to adjacent spend) plus a deliberate value-capture strategy with a specific data point.

quotes.topic_title: Pricing: willingness-to-pay, elasticity, and process
quotes.text: It's really like an all hands on deck conversation. Pricing is so cross-cutting because it's a finance discussion as well. You're modeling out things in spreadsheets and figuring out how that might impact the business. But you can't just solve these problems in spreadsheets. You have to go talk to customers, test the waters, understand where people's appetites are and sussing that out is really hard.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: An actionable process insight: pricing changes require cross-functional work and direct customer testing beyond spreadsheet modeling.

quotes.topic_title: Pricing: willingness-to-pay, elasticity, and process
quotes.text: people aren't very willing to share explicitly what they will pay. But there's some tools that we use on relative value. People most think about what is the relative value of dbt in their cloud warehouse. And we also tried to employ some of the tactics that we tried to suss out what do people view as very inexpensive? What's a price point that's very cheap or a no-brainer? What price point is maybe fair or comfortable for them and what would be too expensive?
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A practical methodology for eliciting willingness-to-pay via relative value anchoring and price-point ladders (cheap/no-brainer/fair/too expensive).

quotes.topic_title: Selling in tough times: be transparent and widen net
quotes.text: I think it's good advice. If you're in a Hail Mary situation where you're looking for a home or you need an exit for your business, it's better to be transparent and cast a wider net.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A clear, actionable strategy shift for distressed startups: go public/transparent and broaden outreach rather than running a quiet process.

quotes.topic_title: Selling in tough times: be transparent and widen net
quotes.text: So the better approach is just to be transparent and I see it pretty regularly and there's absolutely no shame in sending a note that says something like, "Hey, we're looking for an exit for our company X, Y, and Z didn't pan out as we expected. We built a really interesting product and we want to keep the team together. We're running a process. Are you interested?" Really just as simple as that.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Provides a concrete outreach script founders can copy-paste when initiating an M&A/acqui-hire process under pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Selling in tough times: be transparent and widen net
quotes.text: Yeah. Usually in these situations people are acquiring the teams and so having your data room together, really the most important thing is these are the team members that are going to come along with the acquisition is the biggest motivator for why a buyer would get excited.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Reframes “selling the company” as “selling the team,” emphasizing what to prioritize in materials and diligence for acqui-hire style outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Selling in tough times: be transparent and widen net
quotes.text: If the company is buying a lot or they're active, they often have corp dev teams and so use that corp dev team to your advantage. It's their job to meet absolutely every company that could be potentially interested. So take that meeting, say you're not interested in an acquisition just yet, but push them to make an introduction to someone that could sponsor the deal. So usually that's someone in product or maybe a GM and use that as a starting point for maybe just a conversation, maybe something more like a partnership but get the corp dev team to work for you.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A practical methodology for planting acquisition seeds early: leverage corp dev as a routing function to reach internal deal sponsors.

quotes.topic_title: Selling in tough times: be transparent and widen net
quotes.text: Maybe this is a unpopular thing to say on a podcast, but your investors understand that they're not making their money back. And what they want to do instead is have you end up at a really great company like an Airbnb because that will help them down the road.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance for founders in dire straits: optimize for long-term relationships and landing well, not just returning capital.

quotes.topic_title: M&A market conditions, buyer selection, and messaging
quotes.text: I think founders forget that it is so risky investing in early stage companies that 50% of portfolios investments don't return anything.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A grounding data point that helps founders calibrate expectations about failure rates and investor outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: M&A market conditions, buyer selection, and messaging
quotes.text: So there are a number of reasons why people might sit out, but what I would do if I were in a position of wanting to sell my company is I would come up with a buyer set of maybe a dozen and really there aren't more than a dozen companies that will find what you're doing to be a very good fit.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A practical buyer-selection framework: start with a realistic, small buyer universe rather than a broad outreach.

quotes.topic_title: M&A market conditions, buyer selection, and messaging
quotes.text: But if you still have some room, I would maybe focus on two to three partner or buyers and really play a different playbook, which is inflict pain. Make it really hard for them to not notice you but do it with a smile and be friendly at while you do that.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Counterintuitive M&A outreach tactic: concentrate effort on a few best-fit buyers and create urgency/pressure without burning goodwill.

quotes.topic_title: M&A market conditions, buyer selection, and messaging
quotes.text: If you have time, then don't talk about M&A at all. That's the last thing that you want to speak about.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: Messaging advice for founders with runway: avoid signaling “for sale” and instead lead with collaboration to preserve leverage.

quotes.topic_title: M&A market conditions, buyer selection, and messaging
quotes.text: So the peak was really November of 2021.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A specific market reference point used to explain why deal activity may return as valuation expectations reset post-peak.

quotes.topic_title: dbt company values and operating principles
quotes.text: The value that I shared is we are more concerned with value creation than value capture and that really drives everything that we do.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A clear guiding principle that can shape product, community, and go-to-market decisions toward long-term trust and impact.

quotes.topic_title: dbt company values and operating principles
quotes.text: We try to put a lot of good out into the world and it pays back slowly.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that investing in community and goodwill can compound over time rather than immediately monetizing.

quotes.topic_title: dbt company values and operating principles
quotes.text: Transparency wins. We're a really transparent company. We share our board decks.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A concrete, high-bar example of operational transparency that teams can emulate to increase alignment and trust.

quotes.topic_title: dbt company values and operating principles
quotes.text: We have hard conversations in the open.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: An actionable cultural practice that encourages directness and shared context instead of private backchannels.

quotes.topic_title: dbt company values and operating principles
quotes.text: And then another one is just work done well as its own end and it's really focusing on the journey and not the end destination.
quotes.speaker: Julia Schottenstein
quotes.context: A craftsmanship-oriented mental model that prioritizes quality and process over purely outcome-driven shortcuts.
